STAR: A general interactive framework for FDR¬†control under structural constraints

Lihua Lei lihualei@stanford.edu Departments of Statistics, Stanford University
202 Sequoia Hall, Stanford, CA94305, U.S.A. ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Aaditya Ramdas aramdas@cmu.edu Department of Statistics and Data Science, Carnegie Mellon University
132H Baker Hall, CMU, Pittsburgh, PA15232, U.S.A. ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ William Fithian wfithian@berkeley.edu Departments of Statistics, University of California, Berkeley
301 Evans Hall, UC Berkeley, Berkeley, CA94720, U.S.A.
Abstract

We propose a general framework based on selectively traversed accumulation rules (STAR) ¬†for interactive multiple testing with generic structural constraints on the rejection set. It combines accumulation tests from ordered multiple testing with data-carving ideas from post-selection inference, allowing for highly flexible adaptation to generic structural information. Our procedure defines an interactive protocol for gradually pruning a candidate rejection set, beginning with the set of all hypotheses and shrinking with each step. By restricting the information at each step via a technique we call masking, our protocol enables interaction while controlling the false discovery rate (FDR) in finite samples for any data-adaptive update rule that the analyst may choose. We suggest update rules for a variety of applications with complex structural constraints, show that STAR¬†performs well for problems ranging from convex region detection to FDR¬†control on directed acyclic graphs, and show how to extend it to regression problems where knockoff statistics are available in lieu of pùëùp-values.

keywords:
interactive multiple testing, data carving, masking, knockoffs, false discovery rate, accumulation test
‚Ä†‚Ä†journal: Biometrika

1 Introduction

A classical statistical perspective divides data analysis into two distinct types: exploratory analysis is a flexible and iterative process of searching the data for interesting patterns while only pursuing a loose error guarantee, or none at all, while confirmatory analysis involves performing targeted inferences on questions that were pre-selected for focused study. Selective inference blends exploratory and confirmatory analysis by allowing for inference on questions that may be selected in a data-adaptive way, but most selective inference methods still require the analyst to pre-commit to selection rules before observing the data, falling short of the freewheeling nature of true exploratory analysis. By contrast, interactive methods are a subset of selective inference methods allowing the analyst to react to data, consult her own internal judgment, and revise her models and research plans to adapt to patterns she may not have expected to find, while still achieving valid inferences.

We consider the problem of multiple hypothesis testing with pùëùp-values p1,‚Ä¶,pnsubscriptùëù1‚Ä¶subscriptùëùùëõp_{1},\ldots,p_{n}, with each pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i} corresponding to a different null hypothesis HisubscriptùêªùëñH_{i}. A multiple testing method examines the pùëùp-values, possibly along with additional data, and decides which null hypotheses to reject. Let ‚Ñã0={i:Hi‚Äã¬†is true}subscript‚Ñã0conditional-setùëñsubscriptùêªùëñ¬†is true\mathcal{H}_{0}=\{i:\;H_{i}\text{ is true}\} denote the set of truly null hypotheses and let ‚Ñõ={i:Hi‚Äã¬†is rejected}‚Ñõconditional-setùëñsubscriptùêªùëñ¬†is rejected\mathcal{R}=\{i:\;H_{i}\text{ is rejected}\} denote the rejection set. Then R=|‚Ñõ|ùëÖ‚ÑõR=\left|\mathcal{R}\right| is the number of rejections and V=|‚Ñõ‚à©‚Ñã0|ùëâ‚Ñõsubscript‚Ñã0V=\left|\mathcal{R}\cap\mathcal{H}_{0}\right| is the number of erroneous rejections. Benjamini & Hochberg (1995) defined the false discovery proportion (FDP) as V/max‚Å°{1,R}ùëâ1ùëÖV/\max\{1,R\} and famously proposed controlling its expectation, the false discovery rate (FDR), at some pre-specified level Œ±ùõº\alpha.

This work proposes a new framework for interactive multiple testing in structured settings with FDR¬†control, called selectively traversed accumulation rules (STAR). Our method is especially well-suited to settings where we wish to impose structural constraints on the set of rejected hypotheses ‚Äî for example, to enforce a hierarchy principle for interactions in a regression or analysis of variance (ANOVA) problem, or to detect a convex spatial region where the signal exceeds a certain level in a signal processing application. In certain cases, enforcing a structural constraint is important for logical coherence or interpretability. For instance, in the case of hierarchical testing (e.g. Yekutieli, 2008) where hypotheses are represented as nodes on a tree, the parent of a rejected hypothesis must be rejected as well. In other cases, the structural constraint serves as a type of side information which reflects the scientific domain knowledge. By using this information judiciously, the statistical power may be boosted if the true signals meet the constraint, exactly or at least approximately.

More formally, our procedure controls the FDR¬†in finite samples while guaranteeing that the rejection set ‚Ñõ‚ààùí¶‚Ñõùí¶\mathcal{R}\in\mathcal{K} where ùí¶ùí¶\mathcal{K} is a collection of subsets satisfying the constraint. For instance, in the case of hierarchical testing, ùí¶ùí¶\mathcal{K} includes all subsets that correspond to rooted subtrees. The notion of structure is meant in a rather general way: ùí¶ùí¶\mathcal{K} might also depend on auxiliary covariate information xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} about the hypothesis HisubscriptùêªùëñH_{i}. For instance, in the spatial testing setting, xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} gives the geographic location in ‚Ñù2superscript‚Ñù2\mathbb{R}^{2} and ùí¶ùí¶\mathcal{K} may include all subsets that can be written as the intersection of a convex set on ‚Ñù2superscript‚Ñù2\mathbb{R}^{2} with (xi)i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñùëñ1ùëõ(x_{i})_{i=1}^{n}.

STAR¬†generalizes the notion of masking used by the adaptive p-value thresholding (AdaPT) method of Lei & Fithian (2018), which achieves its error control guarantee by judiciously limiting the analyst‚Äôs knowledge about the data. As such, it is natural to view STAR¬†as an iterative interaction between two agents: the analyst, who drives the search for discoveries based on partial observation of the data, and a hypothetical oracle, who observes the full data set and gradually reveals information to the analyst based on her actions. Typically the oracle is a computer program and the analyst is either a human or an automated adaptive search algorithm based on pre-defined modeling assumptions. In Section¬†3 we discuss generic strategies for defining good automated rules.

A key difference between STAR¬†and most earlier works is that they give the analyst power to enforce structural constraints on the final rejection set. Previous works such as the Benjamini-Hochberg (BH) procedure (Benjamini & Hochberg, 1995), independent hypothesis weighting (IHW) (Ignatiadis et¬†al., 2016), structure-adaptive Benjamini-Hochberg algorithm (SABHA) (Li & Barber, 2019) and AdaPT¬†(Lei & Fithian, 2018) all produce potentially heterogeneous thresholds for pùëùp-values and then reject all hypotheses whose pùëùp-values are below their corresponding thresholds. Because any given pùëùp-value could be above the chosen threshold, none of these methods can enforce structural constraints. On the other hand, there are various other algorithms that are tailored to particular structural constraints, e.g. Yekutieli (2008); Lynch & Guo (2016) for hierarchical testing on trees and Lynch & Guo (2016); Ramdas et¬†al. (2019a) for testing on directed acyclic graphs. However, these methods are non-adaptive and non-interactive in the sense that they can neither learn the structural information from data nor incorporate extra side information, and they apply to very specific types of constraints. To our knowledge, our method is the first data adaptive and interactive multiple testing framework that can impose generic structural constraints on the rejection set.

2 Selectively Traversed Accumulation Rules

2.1 The framework

We assume that for each hypothesis HisubscriptùêªùëñH_{i}, i=1,‚Ä¶,nùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëõi=1,\ldots,n, the oracle observes a generic covariate xi‚ààùí≥subscriptùë•ùëñùí≥x_{i}\in\mathcal{X} and a pùëùp-value pi‚àà[0,1]subscriptùëùùëñ01p_{i}\in[0,1]; Section¬†6 discusses a generalization to the setting where we have knockoff statistics instead of pùëùp-values. We require that ‚àÖ‚ààùí¶ùí¶\emptyset\in\mathcal{K}.

To allow for the analyst to make data-dependent choices without inflating Type I error, we generalize a technique by Lei & Fithian (2018) called masking. Specifically, for any choice of accumulation function h‚Ñéh as described above, we show how to derive a masking function gùëîg, constructed so that h‚Äã(p)‚Ñéùëùh(p) is mean-independent of g‚Äã(p)ùëîùëùg(p) when p‚àºU‚Äã[0,1]similar-toùëùùëà01p\sim U[0,1].

For example, if we choose h‚Äã(p)=2‚ãÖùüè‚Äã{p‚â•0.5}‚Ñéùëù‚ãÖ21ùëù0.5h(p)=2\cdot\mathbf{1}\{p\geq 0.5\}, then we may choose g‚Äã(p)=min‚Å°{p,1‚àíp}ùëîùëùùëù1ùëùg(p)=\min\{p,1-p\}, by observing that for a null uniform pùëùp-value pùëùp, we have ùîº‚Äã[h‚Äã(p)|g‚Äã(p)]=ùîº‚Äã[h‚Äã(p)]=1ùîºdelimited-[]conditional‚Ñéùëùùëîùëùùîºdelimited-[]‚Ñéùëù1\mathbb{E}[h(p)|g(p)]=\mathbb{E}[h(p)]=1. Section¬†2.3 describes a general recipe for constructing such a function gùëîg. Even though the masking function gùëîg is constructed using condition (2), we next show that when null pùëùp-values are not exactly uniform, the same g,hùëî‚Ñég,h pairs satisfy a more general property that will be crucial in the proof of FDR¬†control. The proof is presented in Appendix A.1.

Proposition 2.1.

If the density of a null pùëùp-value pùëùp is non-decreasing and functions h,g‚Ñéùëîh,g are chosen such that condition¬†(2) holds, then we have

ùîº‚Äã[h‚Äã(p)‚à£g‚Äã(p)]‚â•1‚Äã¬†almost surely.ùîºdelimited-[]conditional‚Ñéùëùùëîùëù1¬†almost surely\mathbb{E}[h(p)\mid g(p)]\geq 1\,\,\mbox{ almost surely}.

The STAR¬†protocol works by first revealing all masked pùëùp-values g‚Äã(pi)ùëîsubscriptùëùùëñg(p_{i})s to the analyst. Then, as the analyst shrinks the rejection set, pùëùp-values that can no longer be rejected get unmasked, meaning that the analyst observes all of the pùëùp-values pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i} for i‚àâ‚Ñõtùëñsubscript‚Ñõùë°i\notin\mathcal{R}_{t}. Revealing g‚Äã(p)ùëîùëùg(p) to the analyst is an example of data carving (Fithian et¬†al., 2014), where a part of a random variable, g‚Äã(pi)ùëîsubscriptùëùùëñg(p_{i}), is used for selection, while the remainder h‚Äã(pi)‚Ñésubscriptùëùùëñh(p_{i}) is used for inference. Because these two views of the data are designed to be orthogonal to each other under the null, the masked pùëùp-values and covariates together, along with prior information, provide guidance to the analyst on how to adaptively shrink the rejection set. Unlike other approaches (e.g. Dwork et¬†al., 2015), masking does not introduce extra randomness. This is desirable in scientific research to prevent cheating by specifying a favorable random seed.

At each step tùë°t, the oracle reports FDP^tsubscript^FDPùë°\widehat{\textnormal{FDP}}_{t} to the analyst. If FDP^t‚â§Œ±subscript^FDPùë°ùõº\widehat{\textnormal{FDP}}_{t}\leq\alpha, then the entire procedure halts and ‚Ñõtsubscript‚Ñõùë°\mathcal{R}_{t} is rejected. Otherwise, the analyst is responsible to select a smaller rejection set ‚Ñõt+1‚ää‚Ñõtsubscript‚Ñõùë°1subscript‚Ñõùë°\mathcal{R}_{t+1}\subsetneq\mathcal{R}_{t} using covariates, intuition, and any desired statistical model or procedure, along with the oracle‚Äôs revealed information, subject to the constraint that ‚Ñõt+1‚ààùí¶subscript‚Ñõùë°1ùí¶\mathcal{R}_{t+1}\in\mathcal{K}. After the analyst chooses ‚Ñõt+1subscript‚Ñõùë°1\mathcal{R}_{t+1}, the oracle then re-estimates the FDP¬†and reveals pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i} for i‚àà‚Ñõt‚àñ‚Ñõt+1ùëñsubscript‚Ñõùë°subscript‚Ñõùë°1i\in\mathcal{R}_{t}\setminus\mathcal{R}_{t+1}. Remark 2.2.

In some applications, the analyst may want to choose the structural constraint ùí¶ùí¶\mathcal{K} after looking at data. Indeed, STAR¬†allows ùí¶ùí¶\mathcal{K} to be chosen based on ‚Ñ±0subscript‚Ñ±0\mathcal{F}_{0} and even to vary with tùë°t. Likewise, there is no requirement that ‚Ñõt‚ààùí¶subscript‚Ñõùë°ùí¶\mathcal{R}_{t}\in\mathcal{K} for every tùë°t, provided we require ‚Ñõt‚ààùí¶subscript‚Ñõùë°ùí¶\mathcal{R}_{t}\in\mathcal{K} as an additional requirement for stopping the algorithm. We discuss these details in Appendix B.2 to avoid extra complication.

The mechanisms used by STAR¬†to enforce structural constraints and to learn structural information are different. The former is enabled by the fact that ‚Ñõt+1subscript‚Ñõùë°1\mathcal{R}_{t+1} can be updated without relying on the size of pùëùp-values, in contrast to BH-type algorithms, while the latter is enabled by masking functions which provide a partial view of data without sacrificing validity.

STAR¬†can be viewed as a generalization of the ordered multiple testing setting of Li & Barber (2016), in which a full pre-ordering of hypotheses based on outside data or prior knowledge must be supplied as an input to the analysis, and with a low-quality pre-ordering the method may be powerless, as shown in Li & Barber (2016) and Lei & Fithian (2016). By contrast, for our method, a pre-ordering is just one potential source of side information that may or may not be available in any given case; other possibilities include spatial structure, covariate information, or a partial ordering from a directed acyclic graph (DAG). Our method then determines a data-adaptive ordering using interactive guidance from the scientist, or an algorithm acting on their behalf. This interactive ordering respects any constraints the analyst has imposed, and using both the side information and the masked pùëùp-values g‚Äã(pi)ùëîsubscriptùëùùëñg(p_{i}). This interactive ordering, which is the counterpart to accumulation tests‚Äô pre-ordering, is simply the order in which the scientist/algorithm decides to peel off unpromising hypotheses from the candidate rejection set, based on masked pùëùp-values and prior information. If the ordering is pre-specified before seeing the data and masked pùëùp-values are ignored entirely, and there is no interaction, then our method reduces to an accumulation test, with HnsubscriptùêªùëõH_{n} peeled off first, then Hn‚àí1subscriptùêªùëõ1H_{n-1}, and so on.

The flexibility of our method is enabled by carving the pùëùp-value into two parts g‚Äã(p)ùëîùëùg(p) and h‚Äã(p)‚Ñéùëùh(p), where the first is used to adaptively determine the ordering, and the second part is used for controlling the FDR. Our use of the masked pùëùp-values is a selective-inference free lunch: compared to accumulation tests, we are using the same h‚Äã(pi)‚Ñésubscriptùëùùëñh(p_{i}) values in the same way to estimate the FDP; we have brought more information g‚Äã(pi)ùëîsubscriptùëùùëñg(p_{i}) to bear on guiding our methodology without inflating the FDR¬†or requiring any further correction. In other words, accumulation tests can be thought of as also calculating g‚Äã(pi)ùëîsubscriptùëùùëñg(p_{i}) values and then simply discarding them. On the other hand, the masked pùëùp-values can be highly informative about which hypotheses are non-null. For example, to observe that g‚Äã(pi)=min‚Å°{pi,1‚àípi}=10‚àí8ùëîsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ1subscriptùëùùëñsuperscript108g(p_{i})=\min\{p_{i},1-p_{i}\}=10^{-8} is extremely suggestive (a) that HisubscriptùêªùëñH_{i} is most likely false, (b) that h‚Äã(pi)=2‚ÄãI‚Äã(pi>0.5)‚Ñésubscriptùëùùëñ2ùêºsubscriptùëùùëñ0.5h(p_{i})=2I(p_{i}>0.5) is most likely 0, and possibly (c) that other hypotheses HjsubscriptùêªùëóH_{j} with nearby spatial locations or covariate values to HisubscriptùêªùëñH_{i} are more likely to be false as well and have h‚Äã(pj)‚âà0‚Ñésubscriptùëùùëó0h(p_{j})\approx 0. More generally, by examining in aggregate all of the masked pùëùp-values, and most of the unmasked ones too in later stages of the procedure, we can learn areas of the covariate space with many non-null hypotheses and focus the power on those by placing them closer to the front of the list, that is, by peeling them off last. When the true signals do not meet the constraint, the enforced constraint narrows down potential rejection sets and may affect power negatively compared to algorithms which do not enforce the constraint; however, the data-adaptive exploration made possible by masking allows users to learn the structure that could compensate for the power loss at no cost of false discoveries. In fact, the theory and algorithm would be exactly identical if the prespecified ùí¶ùí¶\mathcal{K} is replaced by a data-dependent constraint ùí¶tsubscriptùí¶ùë°\mathcal{K}_{t}, as long as ùí¶tsubscriptùí¶ùë°\mathcal{K}_{t} is predictable, that is ùí¶tsubscriptùí¶ùë°\mathcal{K}_{t} is ‚Ñ±t‚àí1subscript‚Ñ±ùë°1\mathcal{F}_{t-1}-measurable.

In Appendix I, we conduct an asymptotic analysis under a slightly more general framework of Li & Barber (2016) to quantify the benefit of using masking functions. In a nutshell, in the absence of an informative pre-ordering, the accumulation test is powerless while the masking functions have some power in most practical cases. Moreover, even when an informative pre-ordering is available, we can still improve the power further by combining it with the masked pùëùp-values to obtain an even better ordering.

2.2 False discovery rate control

Intuitively, the quantity ‚àëi‚àà‚Ñõth‚Äã(pi)subscriptùëñsubscript‚Ñõùë°‚Ñésubscriptùëùùëñ\sum_{i\in\mathcal{R}_{t}}h(p_{i}) is a conservative estimator of Vt=|‚Ñã0‚à©‚Ñõt|subscriptùëâùë°subscript‚Ñã0subscript‚Ñõùë°V_{t}=|\mathcal{H}_{0}\cap\mathcal{R}_{t}|, the number of false rejections we would incur if we rejected the set ‚Ñõtsubscript‚Ñõùë°\mathcal{R}_{t}: each null hypothesis in ‚Ñõtsubscript‚Ñõùë°\mathcal{R}_{t} contributes at least 1 in expectation, and the non-null hypotheses contribute a non-negative amount. Hence |‚Ñõt|‚àí1‚Äã‚àëi‚àà‚Ñõth‚Äã(pi)superscriptsubscript‚Ñõùë°1subscriptùëñsubscript‚Ñõùë°‚Ñésubscriptùëùùëñ|\mathcal{R}_{t}|^{-1}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{R}_{t}}h(p_{i}) can be interpreted as an upwardly biased estimator of the FDP¬†of rejection set ‚Ñõtsubscript‚Ñõùë°\mathcal{R}_{t}. With the correction term in equation (1), we can prove that Algorithm¬†2.1 controls FDR¬†in finite samples however the analyst update the rejection set ‚Ñõtsubscript‚Ñõùë°\mathcal{R}_{t}, under certain regularity conditions on the joint distribution of pùëùp-values.

3 Implementation

3.1 Guidance to update rejection sets

Theorem¬†2.3 showed that the FDR¬†is controlled no matter how the analyst chooses ‚Ñõt+1subscript‚Ñõùë°1\mathcal{R}_{t+1} based on ‚Ñ±tsubscript‚Ñ±ùë°\mathcal{F}_{t}; however, having a good update rule will be vital to operationalizing STAR¬†in any given context. Still, we recommend that any human-in-the-loop interactions be grounded in principled data analysis. For example, our method is to some degree susceptible to the same free-rider dynamic as other data-adaptive multiple testing procedures like AdaPT and knockoffs: namely, if we find 100 strong signals in one part of the data set, we might be able to throw in two or three more favorite hypotheses from elsewhere without threatening false discovery rate control. Well-chosen and principled constraints on the rejection set can serve as a safeguard against this behavior, which is epistemically problematic even if not formally disallowed. In addition, too-frequent looks at the data may tempt users to look back and modify their previous rejection sets; such actions are prohibited by Theorem¬†2.3 and would break the theoretical guarantee.

In general, we can describe an update rule in three steps: (1) find all candidate sets of hypotheses that we can peel off from ‚Ñõtsubscript‚Ñõùë°\mathcal{R}_{t} without leaving the constraint set ùí¶ùí¶\mathcal{K}; (2) compute a score using all the information in ‚Ñ±tsubscript‚Ñ±ùë°\mathcal{F}_{t} that measures the likelihood that each candidate set has non-nulls; and (3) delete the candidate set with the worst score. We provide a flowchart in Section B.1 summarizing the pipeline schematically. The inclusion of candidate set marks the fundamental difference between STAR¬†and AdaPT¬†because the essential candidate sets of the latter are simply all remaining hypotheses while the former operates in a more greedy way.

As a concrete example, suppose that the hypotheses correspond to vertices of a tree and one aims at detecting a rooted subtree of signals. Then the deletion candidates are all hypotheses on leaf nodes of the subtree given by ‚Ñõtsubscript‚Ñõùë°\mathcal{R}_{t} because deletion of any leaf node does not change the rooted subtree structure of the rejection set.

The next step is to compute a score for each candidate. Heuristically, the score should be highly correlated to the pùëùp-values. As discussed in Section 2, the most straightforward score for the iùëñi-th hypothesis is g‚Äã(pi)ùëîsubscriptùëùùëñg(p_{i}). We refer to it as the canonical score. For candidate sets that contains multiple hypotheses, we define the canonical score as the average of g‚Äã(pi)ùëîsubscriptùëùùëñg(p_{i})‚Äôs. A larger canonical score gives stronger evidence that the candidate set is mostly null. Although the canonical score is straightforward to use, the user is allowed to fit any model using the covariates and the partially-masked pùëùp-values. Thus, one can estimate the signal strength, or a posterior probability of being null, as the score: we call this a model-assisted score.

Finally, given the score, it is natural to remove the least favorable candidate. For instance, when using the canonical score, the candidate with largest score will be removed. On the other hand, if the score measures the signal strength or the likelihood of being non-null, the candidate with smallest score will be removed.

Our principle here can be summarized as follows: given a working model or belief about the data generating process, we have a generic EM-algorithm based pipeline that incorporates it into our method to produce scores yielding the adaptive ordering. The researcher can always incorporate their favorite data-generating model into our method, improving power if their model is correct/good, but never violating the FDR¬†control if their model is inaccurate.

3.2 Conditional one-group model as the working model

Although the canonical scores are effective in many cases as will be shown in Section 5, they do not fully exploit covariate information, apart from enforcing the constraint. For instance, when the hypotheses are arranged spatially, we may expect the non-nulls will concentrate on a few clusters, and/or that the signal strength will be smooth on the underlying space. This prior knowledge may neither be reflected directly from the pùëùp-values nor be explicitly used to strengthen the pùëùp-values; instead, we can use a working model to assist calculating the scores. We emphasize that no matter how misspecified our working model is, the FDR¬†is still controlled.

Lei & Fithian (2018) proposed a conditional two-group model and used the estimated local FDR¬†as model-assisted scores. They proved in their Theorem 2 that the local FDR¬†gives the optimal score to order hypotheses. The model can be fitted by an expectation-maximization (EM) algorithm (Appendix A of Lei & Fithian, 2018).

Despite the approximate optimality of the above approach, the EM¬†algorithm for conditional two-group models is computationally intensive because it fits two separate models for the proportion and the signal strength of non-nulls at each iteration. Additionally, Lei & Fithian (2018) pointed out in their Appendix A.3 some instability issues of the algorithm. For these reasons, we proposed a conditional one-group model as an alternative:

pi‚àºf‚Äã(p;Œºi)with¬†‚ÄãŒ∑‚Äã(Œºi)=Œ≤‚Ä≤‚Äãœï‚Äã(xi),formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscriptùëùùëñùëìùëùsubscriptùúáùëñwith¬†ùúÇsubscriptùúáùëñsuperscriptùõΩ‚Ä≤italic-œïsubscriptùë•ùëñ\displaystyle p_{i}\sim f(p;\mu_{i})\quad\text{with }\eta(\mu_{i})=\beta^{\prime}\phi(x_{i}), (5)

where fùëìf is the density function, Œ∑ùúÇ\eta is the link function and œïitalic-œï\phi is an arbitrary featurization. As will be detailed in Appendix B.4, Œºisubscriptùúáùëñ\mu_{i} can be estimated via an EM¬†algorithm. The model-assisted scores are then given by the estimates Œº^isubscript^ùúáùëñ\hat{\mu}_{i}. Although Œº^isubscript^ùúáùëñ\hat{\mu}_{i}‚Äôs lose the optimality guarantee, they provide good proxy of how promising each hypothesis is. On the other hand, (5) is easier to fit as it only involves one set of parameters. At step tùë°t, the algorithm only needs to impute the masked pùëùp-values. Thus it is computationally more efficient and partly solves the issue raised in Lei & Fithian (2018).

Finally, as discussed in Lei & Fithian (2018), pùëùp-values may not be the objects that are most amenable to modeling, in which case one can either model transformed pùëùp-values or directly model the data used to produce them. For instance, in many applications, z-values are available and one-sided pùëùp-values are obtained by the transformation pi=1‚àíŒ¶‚Äã(zi)subscriptùëùùëñ1Œ¶subscriptùëßùëñp_{i}=1-\Phi(z_{i}), where Œ¶Œ¶\Phi is the distribution function of a standard Gaussian. In this case, we can directly model zisubscriptùëßùëñz_{i} as zi‚àºN‚Äã(Œºi,1)similar-tosubscriptùëßùëñùëÅsubscriptùúáùëñ1z_{i}\sim N(\mu_{i},1).

4 Example 1: convex region detection

4.1 Problem Setup

In some applications, the pùëùp-values may be associated with features xi‚ààùí≥‚äÜ‚Ñùdsubscriptùë•ùëñùí≥superscript‚Ñùùëëx_{i}\in\mathcal{X}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{d}, which encode some contextual information such as predictor variables or a spatial location, and which may be associated with the underlying signal. We may wish to use this feature information to discover regions of the feature space where the signal is relatively strong; for example, Drevelegas (2010) seek a convex region to locate the boundary of tumors.

As a concrete mathematical example, suppose that for each point xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} on a regular spatial grid, we observe an independent observation zi‚àºN‚Äã(f‚Äã(xi),1)similar-tosubscriptùëßùëñùëÅùëìsubscriptùë•ùëñ1z_{i}\sim N(f(x_{i}),1) for some non-negative function fùëìf, and we hope to discover the region ùíû={x:f‚Äã(x)>0}ùíûconditional-setùë•ùëìùë•0\mathcal{C}=\{x:\;f(x)>0\}, where we have some prior belief that ùíûùíû\mathcal{C} is convex; for example, if fùëìf is known to be a concave function, then ùíûùíû\mathcal{C} is a superlevel set and is hence convex. Since we cannot expect to perfectly find ùíûùíû\mathcal{C}, we may hope to discover a smaller region ùíû^^ùíû\widehat{\mathcal{C}} which is mostly contained within ùíûùíû\mathcal{C}, that is,

Vol‚Äã(ùíû^‚à©ùíûc)Vol‚Äã(ùíû^)‚â§Œ±.Vol^ùíûsuperscriptùíûùëêVol^ùíûùõº\frac{\text{Vol}(\widehat{\mathcal{C}}\cap\mathcal{C}^{c})}{\text{Vol}(\widehat{\mathcal{C}})}\leq\alpha. (6)

We can frame the above as a multiple testing problem by computing a one-sided pùëùp-value pi=1‚àíŒ¶‚Äã(zi)subscriptùëùùëñ1Œ¶subscriptùëßùëñp_{i}=1-\Phi(z_{i}) for each HisubscriptùêªùëñH_{i} and constraining the rejection set to be of the form ‚Ñõ={i:xi‚ààùíû^}‚Ñõconditional-setùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ^ùíû\mathcal{R}=\{i:\;x_{i}\in\widehat{\mathcal{C}}\}, for some convex set ùíû^^ùíû\widehat{\mathcal{C}}, leading to a constraint ùí¶ùí¶\mathcal{K} on the allowable rejection sets. If the grid is relatively fine, then FDR¬†is a natural error criterion to control since the FDP¬†of ‚Ñõ‚Ñõ\mathcal{R} approximates criterion (6).

As another application in supervised learning, we may observe a pair of features xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} and response yisubscriptùë¶ùëñy_{i} for i=1,‚Ä¶,nùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëõi=1,\ldots,n, and hope to find a subregion of the feature space ùí≥ùí≥\mathcal{X} where the yùë¶y values tend to be relatively large. In bump-hunting (Friedman & Fisher, 1999), we seek to discover a rectangle in predictor space; Appendix¬†C discusses this application.

More generally, we may want to discover a set of hypotheses ‚Ñõ={i:i‚ààùíû^}‚Ñõconditional-setùëñùëñ^ùíû\mathcal{R}=\{i:\;i\in\widehat{\mathcal{C}}\} where ùíû^^ùíû\widehat{\mathcal{C}} is convex, or is a rectangle, or satisfies some other geometric property. To the best of our knowledge, no previously existing procedure can solve the above problems while guaranteeing FDR¬†control. To implement these goals using the STAR¬†framework, we need only define the procedure-specific functions elaborated in Section 3. To illustrate, we first consider an example where xi‚àà‚Ñù2subscriptùë•ùëñsuperscript‚Ñù2x_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{2}.

4.2 Procedure

To preserve convexity, we consider an automated procedure that gradually peels off the boundaries of the point cloud {xi}subscriptùë•ùëñ\{x_{i}\}. At each iteration, we choose a direction Œ∏‚àà[0,2‚ÄãœÄ)ùúÉ02ùúã\theta\in[0,2\pi) and a small constant Œ¥ùõø\delta, and peel off a proportion Œ¥ùõø\delta of points that are farthest along this direction.

Specifically, for each angle Œ∏ùúÉ\theta, we define a candidate set C‚Äã(Œ∏;Œ¥)ùê∂ùúÉùõøC(\theta;\delta) to be observed as the set of indices corresponding to the Œ¥ùõø\delta-proportion of points that are farthest along the direction Œ∏ùúÉ\theta.

If the goal is to detect an axis-parallel box, Œ∏ùúÉ\theta can be restricted to only take values in {0,œÄ2,œÄ,3‚ÄãœÄ2}0ùúã2ùúã3ùúã2\{0,\frac{\pi}{2},\pi,\frac{3\pi}{2}\}; otherwise we set Œ∏ùúÉ\theta to an equi-spaced grid on [0,2‚ÄãœÄ]02ùúã[0,2\pi] of length 100. Given a score SisubscriptùëÜùëñS_{i} for each hypothesis, which we soon define, we may evaluate the signal strength of each candidate set by the average of SisubscriptùëÜùëñS_{i}. Then we may update ‚Ñõtsubscript‚Ñõùë°\mathcal{R}_{t} as

‚Ñõt:=‚Ñõt‚àí1‚àñC‚Äã(Œ∏^;Œ¥),withŒ∏^:=arg‚ÄãminŒ∏‚Å°Avg‚Äã{Si:i‚ààC‚Äã(Œ∏;Œ¥)}.formulae-sequenceassignsubscript‚Ñõùë°subscript‚Ñõùë°1ùê∂^ùúÉùõøwithassign^ùúÉsubscriptargminùúÉAvgconditional-setsubscriptùëÜùëñùëñùê∂ùúÉùõø\mathcal{R}_{t}:=\mathcal{R}_{t-1}\setminus C(\hat{\theta};\delta),\quad\mbox{with}\quad\hat{\theta}:=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\theta}\mathrm{Avg}\{S_{i}:i\in C(\theta;\delta)\}.

Finally, to define the score SisubscriptùëÜùëñS_{i}‚Äôs, we can directly use the canonical score g‚Äã(pi)ùëîsubscriptùëùùëñg(p_{i}). However, in most problems of this type where xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} represents the location in some continuous space, it is reasonable to assume that the distributions of pùëùp-values are smoothly varying. In particular, we use the conditional one-group model on pùëùp-values with Beta distribution, i.e. pi‚àºBeta‚Äã(1/Œºi,1)similar-tosubscriptùëùùëñBeta1subscriptùúáùëñ1p_{i}\sim\mathrm{Beta}(1/\mu_{i},1), as the working model and fit a generalized additive model (Hastie & Tibshirani, 1990) using the the smooth spline basis of xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} as the featurization œïitalic-œï\phi defined in (5). This working model is motivated by the conditional two-group Gamma generalized linear model in Lei & Fithian (2018).

4.3 Simulation results

We consider an artificial dataset where the predictors form an equi-spaced 50√ó50505050\times 50 grid in the area [‚àí100,100]√ó[‚àí100,100]100100100100[-100,100]\times[-100,100]. Let ùíû0subscriptùíû0\mathcal{C}_{0} be a convex set on ‚Ñù2superscript‚Ñù2\mathbb{R}^{2} and set ‚Ñã0c={xi:xi‚ààùíû0}superscriptsubscript‚Ñã0ùëêconditional-setsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùíû0\mathcal{H}_{0}^{c}=\{x_{i}:x_{i}\in\mathcal{C}_{0}\}. We generate pùëùp-values i.i.d. from a one-sided normal test, i.e.

pi=1‚àíŒ¶‚Äã(zi),andzi‚àºN‚Äã(Œº,1),formulae-sequencesubscriptùëùùëñ1Œ¶subscriptùëßùëñandsimilar-tosubscriptùëßùëñùëÅùúá1p_{i}=1-\Phi(z_{i}),\quad\mbox{and}\quad z_{i}\sim N(\mu,1), (7)

where Œ¶Œ¶\Phi is the cumulative distribution function of N‚Äã(0,1)ùëÅ01N(0,1). For i‚àà‚Ñã0ùëñsubscript‚Ñã0i\in\mathcal{H}_{0} we set Œº=0ùúá0\mu=0 and for i‚àâ‚Ñã0ùëñsubscript‚Ñã0i\not\in\mathcal{H}_{0} we set Œº=2ùúá2\mu=2. Figure¬†1 shows three types of ùíû0subscriptùíû0\mathcal{C}_{0} that we conduct tests on.

Although our procedure is the only one that is able to enforce the convexity, it is still illuminating to compare it with other procedures to examine the power. In particular, we consider the BH¬†procedure (Benjamini & Hochberg, 1995) and AdaPT¬†(Lei & Fithian, 2018). We implement STAR¬†with the model-assisted score based on the generalized additive model.

For each procedure and level Œ±ùõº\alpha, we calculate the FDP¬†and the power as

FDP‚Äã(Œ±)FDPùõº\displaystyle\mathrm{FDP}(\alpha) =|‚Ñõ‚Äã(Œ±)‚à©‚Ñã0||‚Ñõ‚Äã(Œ±)|,power‚Äã(Œ±)=|‚Ñõ‚Äã(Œ±)‚à©‚Ñã0c||‚Ñã0c|,formulae-sequenceabsent‚Ñõùõºsubscript‚Ñã0‚Ñõùõºpowerùõº‚Ñõùõºsuperscriptsubscript‚Ñã0ùëêsuperscriptsubscript‚Ñã0ùëê\displaystyle=\frac{|\mathcal{R}(\alpha)\cap\mathcal{H}_{0}|}{|\mathcal{R}(\alpha)|},\quad\mathrm{power}(\alpha)~{}=\frac{|\mathcal{R}(\alpha)\cap\mathcal{H}_{0}^{c}|}{|\mathcal{H}_{0}^{c}|}, (8)

where ‚Ñõ‚Äã(Œ±)‚Ñõùõº\mathcal{R}(\alpha) is the rejection set at level Œ±ùõº\alpha. We then estimate the FDR¬†and the power by the average of FDP‚Äã(Œ±)FDPùõº\mathrm{FDP}(\alpha) and power‚Äã(Œ±)powerùõº\mathrm{power}(\alpha) over 100 sets of independently generated pùëùp-values. The results are plotted in Figure 2 for a list of Œ±ùõº\alpha‚Äôs from 0.01 to 0.3. We see that our method is comparable to AdaPT, and more powerful than the BH¬†procedure, neither of which enforce the convexity constraint. Furthermore, it is worth mentioning that the model-assisted STAR¬†achieves high power despite using a generic and misspecified generalized additive beta model for the pùëùp-values.

The power gain over the BH¬†procedure is in part from the fact that the convexity constraint reflects the truth and our method implicitly builds it into the selection. It is also driven by the effective learning of underlying spatial structure. To see that, we plot Œº^‚Äã(x)^ùúáùë•\hat{\mu}(x) in Figure 3. The top panel shows the initial score that only uses partially masked pùëùp-values g‚Äã(pi)ùëîsubscriptùëùùëñg(p_{i}) and xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}. The bottom panel shows the oracle result when fitting the model to fully observed pùëùp-values. It is surprising that even the initial estimate is good enough to clearly show the contour of the non-nulls, and is nearly as good as the final estimate using fully observed pùëùp-values; in fact, the correlation between the two estimates is above 0.98 in all three cases. This explains why our method can accurately pinpoint the non-nulls and hence enhance the power.

5 Example 2: testing on directed acyclic graphs

5.1 Setup and Procedure

Another case involves hypotheses arranged on a DAG¬†and the non-nulls are known apriori to satisfy the heredity principle. The strong or weak heredity principle, also referred to as effect hierarchical principle¬†(Wu & Hamada, 2000), states that an effect is significant only if all or one of its parent effects are significant. An application on variable selection in factorial experiments under heredity principle is discussed in Section F.

Multiple testing on DAGs has extensive applications in genomics (e.g., Goeman & Mansmann, 2008; Saunders et¬†al., 2014; Meijer & Goeman, 2015) and clinical trials (e.g., Dmitrienko & Tamhane, 2013). However, most prior work deals with the family-wise error rate (FWER) control, but the setting of FDR¬†control is relatively under-studied. To the best of our knowledge, the only existing FDR¬†control procedures for DAGs were proposed in Gavin Lynch‚Äôs thesis (Lynch, 2014) and in the sequential setting¬†(Ramdas et¬†al., 2019a) and the multi-layer setting¬†(Ramdas et¬†al., 2019b). All aforementioned works were designed for the strong heredity principle.

It is straightforward to apply our method to guarantee FDR¬†control under both the strong and the weak heredity principle. For the strong heredity principle, we select the candidates as all the leaf nodes. For the weak heredity principle, we select the candidates as all nodes by removing which the remaining graph satisfies the principle. We also present an application to a factorial experiment in Appendix F.

5.2 Simulation results

We focus on the strong heredity principle in order to compare STAR¬†with existing methods. To account for the structure, we consider three types of DAGs: shallow regular graph, with 4 layers and 250 nodes in each layer, deep regular graph, with 10 layers and 100 nodes in each layer, and triangular graph, with 5 layers with 50, 100, 200, 300, 350 nodes in each layer respectively. For each graph, we set 50 nodes which satisfy SHP to be non-null and generate pùëùp-values using equation¬†(19) with Œº=2ùúá2\mu=2 for non-nulls. The settings are illustrated in Figure¬†4, with fewer nodes for readability.

We compare our method with canonical scores described in Section 3.1, to the method proposed in Lynch (2014), referred to as Self-Consistent Rejection procedure, as well as a recently developed sequential method, referred to as Greedily Evolving Rejections, a generalization of Lynch‚Äôs hierarchical test by Ramdas et¬†al. (2019a). The results are plotted in Figure 5. It is clear that in all cases our method is more powerful than other methods when Œ±ùõº\alpha is not too small. When Œ±ùõº\alpha is small, our method is powerless in this setting because of the finite sample correction constant h‚Äã(1)‚Ñé1h(1) in (1), which requires at least h‚Äã(1)/Œ±‚àí1‚Ñé1ùõº1h(1)/\alpha-1 rejections to get non-empty rejection set at level Œ±ùõº\alpha. In our case, h‚Äã(1)=2‚Ñé12h(1)=2 but we can reduce h‚Äã(1)‚Ñé1h(1) by choosing other accumulation functions. We provide a few examples that resolve this issue in Appendix G.

6 Discussion

Using knockoff statistics instead of pùëùp-values. We have focused on the case where the test statistics are independent. For more general settings, our framework dovetails naturally with the knockoff framework proposed by Barber & Cand√®s (2015) and extended by Cand√®s et¬†al. (2018), which convert complex regression problems into independent one-bit pùëùp-values for each variable. When running sparse regression algorithms, the underlying variables often have some structure‚Äîfor example, a tree structure with wavelet coefficients in compressed sensing‚Äîand we may want to use the knockoff procedure to select a structured subset of variables.

Keeping this motivation in mind, let WisubscriptùëäùëñW_{i} denote the knockoff statistic for hypothesis iùëñi and define pi=(1+ùüè‚Äã{Wi>0})/2subscriptùëùùëñ11subscriptùëäùëñ02p_{i}=(1+\mathbf{1}\{W_{i}>0\})/2. Then, knockoff constructions guarantee that (pi)i‚àà‚Ñã0subscriptsubscriptùëùùëñùëñsubscript‚Ñã0(p_{i})_{i\in\mathcal{H}_{0}} are independent pùëùp-values, conditional on (|Wi|)i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùëäùëñùëñ1ùëõ(|W_{i}|)_{i=1}^{n} and (pi)i‚àâ‚Ñã0subscriptsubscriptùëùùëñùëñsubscript‚Ñã0(p_{i})_{i\notin\mathcal{H}_{0}}. The absolute value |Wi|subscriptùëäùëñ|W_{i}| may be viewed as the free side-information g‚Äã(pi)ùëîsubscriptùëùùëñg(p_{i}) in Algorithm¬†2.1, while the location of the variable on the tree would be the structural information xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}. Although the constructed pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i} does not technically have a decreasing density, the accumulation function h‚Äã(pi)=2‚ÄãI‚Äã{pi>1/2}=sign‚Äã(Wi)+1‚Ñésubscriptùëùùëñ2ùêºsubscriptùëùùëñ12signsubscriptùëäùëñ1h(p_{i})=2I\{p_{i}>1/2\}=\text{sign}(W_{i})+1 nevertheless has expectation 1 under the null. The analyst may then use STAR¬†to interactively pick a structured subset of variables.

Like AdaPT, knockoffs as defined in Barber & Cand√®s (2015) do not enforce constraints on the rejection set, nor do they allow for interactive adaptation as more pùëùp-values are unmasked. Combining our method with knockoff statistics allows for controlling the FDR¬†in many interesting regression problems with constraints on the rejection set, such as hierarchy constraints for interactions in a regression.

Handling dependence. When the underlying problem is a sparse regression problem, the aforementioned knockoff procedure can be used to construct independent pùëùp-values even when the covariates are not orthogonal. However, it is not yet known how to construct knockoffs in most settings, but we can often still construct dependent pùëùp-values, and it is an important open problem to provide guarantees for such settings. As we show in Appendix H, the experiments under dependence are encouraging, especially under negative dependence, but we do not currently know how to prove any results about robustness to deviations from independence. Such results would immediately be applicable in several other settings, such as ordered testing (Li & Barber, 2016), and knockoffs (Barber & Cand√®s, 2015).

Supplementary Materials

The supplementary materials include all technical proofs (Section A), a more detailed description of STAR¬†(Section B), four more applications on bump hunting, hierarchical testing, wavelet thresholding and interaction selection for factorial experiments (Section C - F), comparison of STAR¬†with different masking functions (Section G), a sensitivity analysis for STAR¬†under dependent p-values (Section H) and an asymptotic power analysis for a subclass of STAR¬†(Section I). The R code to replicate all results in the paper are available at https://github.com/lihualei71/STAR. The sub-folder movies includes GIFs illustrating our method on several applications.

Appendix A Technical Proofs

=h‚Äã(q)‚àíh‚Äã(q~)‚Äã(h‚Äã(q)‚àí1)/(h‚Äã(q~)‚àí1)1‚àí(h‚Äã(q)‚àí1)/(h‚Äã(q~)‚àí1)=1.absent‚Ñéùëû‚Ñé~ùëû‚Ñéùëû1‚Ñé~ùëû11‚Ñéùëû1‚Ñé~ùëû11\displaystyle=\frac{h(q)-h(\tilde{q})(h(q)-1)/(h(\tilde{q})-1)}{1-(h(q)-1)/(h(\tilde{q})-1)}~{}=~{}1. (16)

On the other hand, since s‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùë†‚ãÖs(\cdot) is strictly decreasing, {p:s‚Äã(p)=q}conditional-setùëùùë†ùëùùëû\{p:s(p)=q\} contains at most two points for any qùëûq. As a result,

Pp‚àºU‚Äã([0,1])‚Äã(ùîºp‚àºU‚Äã([0,1])‚Äã[h‚Äã(p)‚à£g‚Äã(p)=q]=1)subscriptùëÉsimilar-toùëùùëà01subscriptùîºsimilar-toùëùùëà01delimited-[]conditional‚Ñéùëùùëîùëùùëû1\displaystyle P_{p\sim U([0,1])}\left(\mathbb{E}_{p\sim U([0,1])}[h(p)\mid g(p)=q]=1\right) ‚â•1‚àíPp‚àºU‚Äã([0,1])‚Äã(s‚àí1‚Äã(ùíü))absent1subscriptùëÉsimilar-toùëùùëà01superscriptùë†1ùíü\displaystyle\geq 1-P_{p\sim U([0,1])}\left(s^{-1}(\mathcal{D})\right)
‚â•1‚àí2‚ÄãPp‚àºU‚Äã([0,1])‚Äã(ùíü)=1.absent12subscriptùëÉsimilar-toùëùùëà01ùíü1\displaystyle\geq 1-2P_{p\sim U([0,1])}(\mathcal{D})~{}=~{}1.

Hence, we have proved that our choice of gùëîg satisfies condition¬†(2), and this concludes the proof of the theorem.

B.2 Data adaptive structural constraint

Let ùí¶0,ùí¶1,‚Ä¶subscriptùí¶0subscriptùí¶1‚Ä¶\mathcal{K}_{0},\mathcal{K}_{1},\ldots be a sequence of structural constraints with ùí¶t‚àà‚Ñ±tsubscriptùí¶ùë°subscript‚Ñ±ùë°\mathcal{K}_{t}\in\mathcal{F}_{t}. We can then generalizes Algorithm 2.1 by incorporating time-varying structural constraints and allowing the rejection set to temporarily leave the constraint. For example, if the analyst had started by wanting to find a convex set, but the masked p-values very clearly reveal a banana shape, or two circles in opposite corners of the grid, then she can change her mind and update ùí¶ùí¶\mathcal{K}.

The above optimization problem is equivalent to solving a weighted MLE on an artificial dataset {(p~t,i)i=1n,(s‚àí1‚Äã(p~t,i))i‚àà‚Ñõt}superscriptsubscriptsubscript~ùëùùë°ùëñùëñ1ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùë†1subscript~ùëùùë°ùëñùëñsubscript‚Ñõùë°\{(\tilde{p}_{t,i})_{i=1}^{n},(s^{-1}(\tilde{p}_{t,i}))_{i\in\mathcal{R}_{t}}\}. Therefore any algorithm that solves the weighted MLE can be embedded into this framework.

We provide two instantiations below, which will be used in later sections. For illustration, we only consider the accumulation function h‚Äã(p)=2‚ÄãI‚Äã(p‚â•0.5)‚Ñéùëù2ùêºùëù0.5h(p)=2I(p\geq 0.5) with s‚Äã(p)=1‚àípùë†ùëù1ùëùs(p)=1-p.

Appendix C Example 3: bump hunting

Bump hunting is widely applied in areas such as astronomy¬†(Good & Gaskins, 1980), risk management¬†(Becker & Fahrmeir, 2001), bioinformatics¬†(Jiang et¬†al., 2006), and epidemiology¬†(Jaffe et¬†al., 2012). In these areas, one collects a response yùë¶y together with a possibly high dimensional vector xùë•x of predictors and aims at obtaining knowledge of f‚Äã(x)=ùîº‚Äã[y|x]ùëìùë•ùîºdelimited-[]conditionalùë¶ùë•f(x)=\mathbb{E}[y|x]. In many applications, it is not necessary to estimate f‚Äã(x)ùëìùë•f(x) uniformly over the domain but simply detect a scientifically interesting subregion of the predictor space instead. In bump hunting, we usually aim to detect a subregion within which the average of yùë¶y is larger than that on the entire space. However, most existing procedures lack formal statistical guarantees.

We can cast the problem as a nonparametric multiple testing problem by defining the null hypothesis HisubscriptùêªùëñH_{i} that the conditional response distribution at the iùëñith data point is

Hi:‚Ñí‚Äã(yi|xi)‚™Ø‚Ñí‚Äã(yi+B),:subscriptùêªùëñprecedes-or-equals‚Ñíconditionalsubscriptùë¶ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ñísubscriptùë¶ùëñùêµH_{i}:\;\mathcal{L}(y_{i}|x_{i})\preceq\mathcal{L}(y_{i}+B),

where ‚™Øprecedes-or-equals\preceq denotes stochastic dominance and ‚Ñí‚Ñí\mathcal{L} denotes the marginal or conditional distribution of yùë¶y. Informally, we wish to find a clustered set of non-nulls, corresponding to a rectangular region of the feature space where the response is unusually large, by some fixed location offset B‚â•0ùêµ0B\geq 0.

Let F0subscriptùêπ0F_{0} denote the marginal distribution function of yùë¶y. If F0subscriptùêπ0F_{0} is known, one can define the pùëùp-value as pi=1‚àíF0‚Äã(yi‚àíB)subscriptùëùùëñ1subscriptùêπ0subscriptùë¶ùëñùêµp_{i}=1-F_{0}(y_{i}-B) (if F0subscriptùêπ0F_{0} is not continuous, we may use a randomized version instead). To discover a rectangular region, we can apply the convex region detection algorithm of Section¬†4.2 with the restriction that we always peel off an axis-parallel rectangle in the form of {i:xi‚Äãj‚â•vj}conditional-setùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñùëósubscriptùë£ùëó\{i:x_{ij}\geq v_{j}\} or {i:xi‚Äãj‚â§vj}conditional-setùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñùëósubscriptùë£ùëó\{i:x_{ij}\leq v_{j}\}. More precisely, given a patience parameter Œ¥‚àà(0,1)ùõø01\delta\in(0,1), the candidate sets are given by {C‚Äã(j,b;Œ¥):j‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,p},b‚àà{‚àí1,1}}conditional-setùê∂ùëóùëèùõøformulae-sequenceùëó1‚Ä¶ùëùùëè11\{C(j,b;\delta):j\in\{1,\ldots,p\},b\in\{-1,1\}\}, where

C‚Äã(j,‚àí1;Œ¥)={i:xi‚Äãj‚â§vj},C‚Äã(j,1;Œ¥)={i:xi‚Äãj‚â•vj},formulae-sequenceùê∂ùëó1ùõøconditional-setùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñùëósubscriptùë£ùëóùê∂ùëó1ùõøconditional-setùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñùëósubscriptùë£ùëóC(j,-1;\delta)=\{i:x_{ij}\leq v_{j}\},\quad C(j,1;\delta)=\{i:x_{ij}\geq v_{j}\},

and vjsubscriptùë£ùëóv_{j} is set to be the minimal value such that |C‚Äã(j,b;Œ¥)|‚â•‚åàn‚ÄãŒ¥‚åâùê∂ùëóùëèùõøùëõùõø|C(j,b;\delta)|\geq\lceil n\delta\rceil.

For illustration, we consider a moderately sized demographics dataset, that contains questions from n=9409ùëõ9409n=9409 questionnaires filled out by shopping mall customers; see Section 14.2.3 of Hastie et¬†al. (2009) for details. The goal is to predict the income using the first 13 questions, listed in the first column of Table¬†1, that provide the basic demographics. All variables are either binary or ordinal. We use the empirical distribution of yisubscriptùë¶ùëñy_{i}, the income, as a proxy for F0subscriptùêπ0F_{0}, and use B=0ùêµ0B=0 for the location offset. Since the yisubscriptùë¶ùëñy_{i}‚Äôs are discrete, the pùëùp-values are made continuous by randomization; to account for the effect of randomization, we repeat the entire experiment 100 times.

We find that the box produced by STAR¬†is quite stable across experiments and the target FDR¬†level Œ±ùõº\alpha. The results are reported in Table¬†1. The last column details the interval for each variable of the most frequent box among 100 repetitions for Œ±‚àà{0.05,0.1,0.2}ùõº0.050.10.2\alpha\in\{0.05,0.1,0.2\}. The middle three columns contain the frequency of this particular box among 100 repetitions. Because the box is quite stable for most predictors, we conclude the randomization of the pùëùp-values does not substantially destabilize the discovered region. We also plot the income distribution of this sub-population and that of the overall population in Figure 8; thus, we see that our method has detected a subpopulation with significantly higher income than the overall population. Compared to other bump hunting algorithms, STAR¬†has statistical guarantees (FDR¬†control).

Appendix D Example 4: hierarchical testing

D.1 Problem Setup

A well-studied case of structured multiple testing is that of hierarchical testing where the hypotheses have an intrinsic rooted tree structure and the non-null hypotheses form a rooted subtree. Most earlier works focus on FWER¬†control¬†(e.g., Dmitrienko et¬†al., 2006; Meinshausen, 2008; Huque & Alosh, 2008; Brechenmacher et¬†al., 2011; Goeman & Finos, 2012). However FWER¬†controlling procedures are often quite conservative, having low power. In contrast, Yekutieli et¬†al. (2006); Yekutieli (2008) proposed a novel procedure in microarray analysis that guarantees FDR¬†control under independence. FDR¬†controlling methods have since been applied to other areas including genomics¬†(e.g., Heller et¬†al., 2009; Guo et¬†al., 2010; Benjamini & Bogomolov, 2014; Li & Ghosh, 2014; Lynch & Guo, 2016) and neural image analysis¬†(e.g., Benjamini & Heller, 2007; Singh & Phillips, 2010; Schildknecht et¬†al., 2016). New procedures have also been recently introduced for multi-layer or multi-resolution FDR¬†guarantees¬†(Barber & Ramdas, 2017; Peterson et¬†al., 2016; Katsevich & Sabatti, 2019; Bogomolov et¬†al., 2017).

Note that in many hierarchical testing problems, the pùëùp-value for a given node is derived from the pùëùp-values of the nodes descending from it (using, for example, the Simes test); in such problems, the pùëùp-values would be dependent and STAR¬†would not be applicable. However, when it is applicable, it is quite straightforward to be applied to hierarchical testing problems. Similar to Section 4, we consider an artificial example to describe the procedure and compare the performance of STAR¬†with other existing methods.

D.2 Procedure

In order to maintain a subtree structure of the rejection set, at any step of the algorithm, we can simply set the candidates to be observed as all leaf nodes of the subtree of still masked pùëùp-values. Equivalently, STAR¬†will peel off the leaf nodes that have least favorable scores at each step.

In this article, we only consider the canonical score. However, it is worth mentioning that there are various reasonable model-assisted scores that can be applied in hierarchical testing. For a certain class of problems such as wavelet-based image-denoising, it is common to assume that the signal strength has an isotonic ordering on the tree under which the signal strength of the parent node is higher than that of the child node. With this prior knowledge, we can combine the EM¬†algorithm and isotonic regression (e.g., Best & Chakravarti, 1990; Mair et¬†al., 2009; Stout, 2013), with a tree ordering, to compute the model-assisted score; See Example 2 in Section B.4 for implementation details.

D.3 Simulations

To illustrate, we construct a balanced binary tree with n=1000ùëõ1000n=1000 nodes and set 50 nodes as non-nulls. We place the non-nulls as the first 50 nodes either in breath-first-search ordering or in depth-first-search ordering. The settings are plotted in Figure¬†9. Heuristically, the methods by Yekutieli (2008) and Lynch & Guo (2016) may prefer the breath-first-search ordering since they are top-down algorithms that proceed layer-by-layer, and only proceed to child nodes when the parent node is rejected. When the non-nulls are placed in the DFS ordering, as shown in the right panel of Figure 9, those methods run the risk of stopping early in the long chain of pùëùp-values, and may therefore be less powerful. By contrast, STAR¬†proceeds adaptively in a bottom-up manner from leaves to the root, and we may expect it to be more robust to the layout of non-nulls.

Another important factor that affects the power is the pattern of signal strength along the tree. The top-down procedures should be more favorable if the signal strength is in an isotonic ordering on the tree where the root node has the strongest signal. However, when the signals in top nodes are weak, these procedures risk being powerless. To account for this effect, we generate pùëùp-values by

pi=1‚àíŒ¶‚Äã(zi),andzi‚àºN‚Äã(Œºi,1).formulae-sequencesubscriptùëùùëñ1Œ¶subscriptùëßùëñandsimilar-tosubscriptùëßùëñùëÅsubscriptùúáùëñ1p_{i}=1-\Phi(z_{i}),\quad\mbox{and}\quad z_{i}\sim N(\mu_{i},1). (19)

where the null Œºisubscriptùúáùëñ\mu_{i}‚Äôs equal 0 and the non-null Œºisubscriptùúáùëñ\mu_{i}‚Äôs are set in one of the following three ways:

  1. [Case 1:]

  2. 1.

    Œºi‚â°2,‚àÄi‚àà‚Ñã0cformulae-sequencesubscriptùúáùëñ2for-allùëñsuperscriptsubscript‚Ñã0ùëê\mu_{i}\equiv 2,\,\,\forall i\in\mathcal{H}_{0}^{c};

  3. 2.

    Œºi={2.5i‚àà{25‚Äã¬†nodes with smallest indices in¬†‚Äã‚Ñã0c},1.5otherwise;subscriptùúáùëñcases2.5ùëñ25¬†nodes with smallest indices in¬†superscriptsubscript‚Ñã0ùëê1.5otherwise;\displaystyle\mu_{i}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}2.5&i\in\{25\mbox{ nodes with smallest indices in }\mathcal{H}_{0}^{c}\},\\ 1.5&\mbox{otherwise;}\end{array}\right.

  4. 3.

    Œºi={1.5i‚àà{25‚Äã¬†nodes with smallest indices in¬†‚Äã‚Ñã0c},2.5otherwise.subscriptùúáùëñcases1.5ùëñ25¬†nodes with smallest indices in¬†superscriptsubscript‚Ñã0ùëê2.5otherwise.\displaystyle\mu_{i}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}1.5&i\in\{25\mbox{ nodes with smallest indices in }\mathcal{H}_{0}^{c}\},\\ 2.5&\mbox{otherwise.}\end{array}\right.

In summary, we consider six cases: the non-nulls are placed in breath-first-search ordering or depth-first-search ordering and the pùëùp-values are set in one of the above three cases. For each setting, we apply STAR, with h‚Äã(p)=2‚ÄãI‚Äã(p‚â•0.5)‚Ñéùëù2ùêºùëù0.5h(p)=2I(p\geq 0.5) and canonical scores, as well as Yekutieli (2008)‚Äôs procedure and Lynch & Guo (2016)‚Äôs procedures in their sections 4.1 and 4.3. We plot the results in Figures¬†10 and¬†11.

From Figure¬†10, we see that all methods control FDR¬†exactly. In cases 1 and 2, STAR¬†has lower power than Lynch & Guo (2016)‚Äôs second procedure, but is competitive with other procedures. When the top non-nulls are weak as in Case 3, the forward procedures lose power remarkably while STAR¬†gains power as expected. It is clearly shown that the power of our method is quite stable across the different layouts as opposed to top-down procedures.

From Figure¬†11, we see that STAR¬†is most powerful even when the non-nulls are placed in a DFS ordering. Comparing to Figure¬†10, the performance of our method does not degrade much. However, the top-down procedures lose power considerably and even become powerless in Case 1 and Case 3.

Appendix E Example 5: wavelet thresholding

Wavelet decomposition has been an efficient tool in signal processing for decades (e.g., Mallat, 1999, and references therein). It provides an efficient and elegant methodology that represents signals at different scales, ranging from ‚Äùbackgrounds/trends‚Äù to ‚Äùedges/anomalies‚Äù.

Due to the hierarchical nature of wavelet decomposition, the wavelet coefficients can be described by a balanced tree. Figure¬†12 gives a schematic description of the 2-dimensional discrete wavelet decomposition which is widely used in image processing. Given an image with size 2k√ó2ksuperscript2ùëòsuperscript2ùëò2^{k}\times 2^{k}, a high-pass filter and a low-pass filter are applied to the rows and columns to decompose the image into four sub-bands, LL, LH, HL and HH, where LL contains all information in lower frequencies and the last three contain the high-frequency information in different orientations. The procedure then proceeds recursively on LL to decompose the low-frequency sub-band as illustrated in panels (a) - (c) of Figure 12 until LL only contains one pixel. The wavelet coefficients can be arranged in a quadtree; See the rightmost panel of Figure 12 for illustration. We refer the readers to Mallat (1999) for details.

Often, natural signals can be represented by a small subset of wavelet coefficients; equivalently, the wavelet coefficient vector is sparse. Under the standard assumption that the signal is multivariate normal and homoscedastic, the wavelet coefficients are independent normal variables since the transformation is unitary. Denote by d^j‚Äãksubscript^ùëëùëóùëò\hat{d}_{jk} the jùëój-th wavelet coefficient in the kùëòk-th level, then d^j‚Äãk‚àºN‚Äã(Œºj‚Äãk,œÉ2)similar-tosubscript^ùëëùëóùëòùëÅsubscriptùúáùëóùëòsuperscriptùúé2\hat{d}_{jk}\sim N(\mu_{jk},\sigma^{2}) for some common variance œÉ2>0superscriptùúé20\sigma^{2}>0. The problem of detecting ‚Äúlarge‚Äù wavelet coefficients can be formalized as a selection problem that aims at detecting nonzero Œºj‚Äãksubscriptùúáùëóùëò\mu_{jk}‚Äôs. The classic procedures, such as hard thresholding (Donoho & Johnstone, 1994) and soft thresholding (Donoho, 1995), are proved to be minimax optimal from the estimation viewpoint. However, for most images it is reasonable to assume that the large coefficients form a subtree (e.g., Shapiro, 1993; Hegde et¬†al., 2015). This tree structure has been exploited since Shapiro (1993)‚Äôs Embedded Zerotrees of Wavelet transforms algorithm for efficient encoding of images.

On the other hand, (Abramovich & Benjamini, 1996) formalized the problem in terms of multiple hypothesis testing with Hj‚Äãk:Œºj‚Äãk=0:subscriptùêªùëóùëòsubscriptùúáùëóùëò0H_{jk}:\mu_{jk}=0 and applied the BH¬†procedure on the pùëùp-values calculated as pj‚Äãk=1‚àíŒ¶‚Äã(d^j‚Äãk/œÉ^)subscriptùëùùëóùëò1Œ¶subscript^ùëëùëóùëò^ùúép_{jk}=1-\Phi(\hat{d}_{jk}/\hat{\sigma}), where œÉ^^ùúé\hat{\sigma} is estimated from the coefficients at the finest scale. This idea is exploited further using Bayesian FDR¬†control methods (e.g., Tadesse et¬†al., 2005; Lavrik et¬†al., 2008).

However, these methods also do not take the structured sparsity into consideration. This motivates us to apply STAR¬†with a tree constraint that is discussed in Section¬†D.2. To illustrate we compare our method with other methods on 48 standard gray-scale images of size 512√ó512512512512\times 512, available at http://decsai.ugr.es/cvg/CG/images/base/XùëãX.gif, where XùëãX is an integer ‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,48}absent1‚Ä¶48\in\{1,\dots,48\}. For each figure we add Gaussian white noise with SNR = 0.5dB, where SNR (signal-to-noise ratio) is defined as 10‚Äãlog10‚Å°(simage2/snoise2)10subscript10superscriptsubscriptùë†image2superscriptsubscriptùë†noise210\log_{10}\left(s_{\mathrm{image}}^{2}/s_{\mathrm{noise}}^{2}\right) with unit dB (decibel). The two panels in the left column of Figure 13 show one original image and its contaminated version.

We compare STAR¬†with the BH¬†procedure (Abramovich & Benjamini, 1996), hard thresholding (Donoho & Johnstone, 1994) and soft thresholding (Donoho, 1995). We estimate the variance œÉ^2superscript^ùúé2\hat{\sigma}^{2} separately for LH, HL and HH sub-bands using the normalized median of the coefficients at the finest scale; See Chapter 11 of Mallat (1999) for details. For STAR¬†and the BH¬†procedure, we calculate pùëùp-values by pj‚Äãk=1‚àíŒ¶‚Äã(d^j‚Äãk/œÉ^w)subscriptùëùùëóùëò1Œ¶subscript^ùëëùëóùëòsubscript^ùúéùë§p_{jk}=1-\Phi(\hat{d}_{jk}/\hat{\sigma}_{w}) where w‚àà{L‚ÄãH,H‚ÄãL,H‚ÄãH}ùë§ùêøùêªùêªùêøùêªùêªw\in\{LH,HL,HH\} depending on the location of d^j‚Äãksubscript^ùëëùëóùëò\hat{d}_{jk}; for hard/soft thresholding, the threshold is chosen as 2‚ÄãœÉ^w2‚Äãlog‚Å°N2superscriptsubscript^ùúéùë§2ùëÅ\sqrt{2\hat{\sigma}_{w}^{2}\log N} where NùëÅN denotes the total number of coefficients. For each method, we record the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and compression ratio (CR), defined as the ratio of the total number of wavelet coefficients and number of selected coefficients. To illustrate, we report the SNRs and CRs on the top of four panels in Figure 13. We observe that STAR¬†has the largest SNR and a more compact representation than the BH¬†procedure. Note that although the BH¬†procedure produces a visually clearer image, the compression ratio is much smaller than other algorithms. For thorough comparison, we compute the ratio of SNR and CR between STAR¬†and other methods and provide the boxplot in Figure 14. It is clearly shown that STAR¬†has larger SNR than other methods and provide a more parsimonious representation than the BH¬†procedure for most figures. We conclude that STAR¬†has reasonable performance in wavelet-based image denoising.

Appendix F Example 6: interaction selection in factorial experiments

The heredity principle dates back to early work of Yates (1937) on factorial experiments. The term ‚Äúheredity‚Äù was coined by Hamada & Wu (1992) in the context of experimental design and originally used to ensure the compatibility of the selected model in the presence of complex aliasing. On the other hand, Nelder (1977) introduced the marginality principle, an equivalent version of the strong heredity principle, driven by interpretability. In recent years, this topic has been revisited under the high dimensional settings (e.g., Yuan et¬†al., 2009; Choi et¬†al., 2010; Bien et¬†al., 2013). However, none of these works provides error measures, either FWER¬†or FDR, regarding the selected variables.

All aforementioned works consider the linear model with all main effects and second-order interaction effects:

y=Œ≤0+‚àëj=1pŒ≤j‚ÄãXj+‚àëj,k=1pŒ≤j‚Äãk‚ÄãXj‚ÄãXk+œµ,ùë¶subscriptùõΩ0superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëùsubscriptùõΩùëósubscriptùëãùëósuperscriptsubscriptùëóùëò1ùëùsubscriptùõΩùëóùëòsubscriptùëãùëósubscriptùëãùëòitalic-œµy=\beta_{0}+\sum_{j=1}^{p}\beta_{j}X_{j}+\sum_{j,k=1}^{p}\beta_{jk}X_{j}X_{k}+\epsilon,

where y‚àà‚Ñùnùë¶superscript‚Ñùùëõy\in\mathbb{R}^{n} is the response variable and (X1,‚Ä¶,Xp)‚àà‚Ñùn√ópsubscriptùëã1‚Ä¶subscriptùëãùëùsuperscript‚Ñùùëõùëù(X_{1},\ldots,X_{p})\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times p} are pùëùp factors. This induces a two-layer DAG¬†with the main effects {Xj}subscriptùëãùëó\{X_{j}\} in the first layer and the interaction effects {Xj‚ÄãXk}subscriptùëãùëósubscriptùëãùëò\{X_{j}X_{k}\} in the second layer. Write ZùëçZ for the design matrix including the intercept term, all main effects and interaction effects, i.e. Z=(1,X1,X2,‚Ä¶,Xp,X1‚ÄãX2,‚Ä¶,Xp‚àí1‚ÄãXp)‚àà‚Ñùn√ó(p2+p+22)ùëç1subscriptùëã1subscriptùëã2‚Ä¶subscriptùëãùëùsubscriptùëã1subscriptùëã2‚Ä¶subscriptùëãùëù1subscriptùëãùëùsuperscript‚Ñùùëõsuperscriptùëù2ùëù22Z=(\textbf{1},\,X_{1},X_{2},\ldots,X_{p},X_{1}X_{2},\ldots,X_{p-1}X_{p})\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times\left(\frac{p^{2}+p+2}{2}\right)} and Œ≤ùõΩ\beta for the coefficients, i.e. Œ≤=(Œ≤0,Œ≤1,‚Ä¶,Œ≤p,Œ≤12,‚Ä¶,Œ≤p‚àí1,p)ùõΩsubscriptùõΩ0subscriptùõΩ1‚Ä¶subscriptùõΩùëùsubscriptùõΩ12‚Ä¶subscriptùõΩùëù1ùëù\beta=(\beta_{0},\beta_{1},\ldots,\beta_{p},\beta_{12},\ldots,\beta_{p-1,p}). Then the model may be succinctly represented as

y=Z‚ÄãŒ≤+œµ.ùë¶ùëçùõΩitalic-œµy=Z\beta+\epsilon.

If one can construct independent pùëùp-values for each entry of Œ≤ùõΩ\beta, STAR¬†can be applied to guarantee the heredity principle and the FDR¬†control simultaneously.

For illustration we consider a pharmaceutical dataset from Jaynes et¬†al. (2013). Their work aims at investigating the effect of six anti-viral drugs, namely Interferon-alpha (A), Interferon-beta (B), Interferon-gamma (C), Ribavirin (D), Acyclovir (E), and TNF-alpha (F), to Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1). They applied a 26‚àí1superscript2612^{6-1} fractional factorial design with 323232 runs and encode all factors by +11+1 and ‚àí11-1 (in fact, they have 35 runs with the last 3 runs being the replicated center points to evaluate the lack-of-fit). The minimal word of the half-fraction design is A‚ÄãB‚ÄãC‚ÄãD‚ÄãE‚ÄãFùê¥ùêµùê∂ùê∑ùê∏ùêπABCDEF and hence it has resolution VI; see Wu & Hamada (2000) for the terminology and details. In other words, the main effects and the second-order interaction effects are not aliased with each other. This means that we can estimate all main effects and all two-factor interactions assuming that fourth-order and higher interactions are negligible, which is quite a reasonable assumption in practice (Jaynes et¬†al., 2013). The response variable is set to be the logarithm of the viral infection load.

Under the standard assumption that œµ‚àºN‚Äã(0,œÉ2‚ÄãIn√ón)similar-toitalic-œµùëÅ0superscriptùúé2subscriptùêºùëõùëõ\epsilon\sim N(0,\sigma^{2}I_{n\times n}), the least-squares estimator is

Due to the nature of fractional factorial designs, ZùëçZ is an orthogonal matrix with

ZT‚ÄãZ=K‚ãÖIK√óK,K=p2+p+22=22.formulae-sequencesuperscriptùëçùëáùëç‚ãÖùêæsubscriptùêºùêæùêæùêæsuperscriptùëù2ùëù2222Z^{T}Z=K\cdot I_{K\times K},\quad K=\frac{p^{2}+p+2}{2}=22.

Thus the entries of Œ≤^^ùõΩ\hat{\beta} are independent. Here we simply replace œÉùúé\sigma by œÉ^^ùúé\hat{\sigma}, obtained from the regression residuals, i.e.

œÉ^2=1n‚àíp2+p+22‚Äã‚Äñy‚àíZ‚ÄãŒ≤^‚Äñ2=110‚Äã‚Äñy‚àíZ‚ÄãŒ≤^‚Äñ2.superscript^ùúé21ùëõsuperscriptùëù2ùëù22superscriptnormùë¶ùëç^ùõΩ2110superscriptnormùë¶ùëç^ùõΩ2\hat{\sigma}^{2}=\frac{1}{n-\frac{p^{2}+p+2}{2}}\|y-Z\hat{\beta}\|^{2}=\frac{1}{10}\|y-Z\hat{\beta}\|^{2}.

Then we can construct the pùëùp-values by

pj=1‚àíŒ¶‚Äã(Œ≤^jœÉ^),pj‚Äãk=1‚àíŒ¶‚Äã(Œ≤^j‚ÄãkœÉ^).formulae-sequencesubscriptùëùùëó1Œ¶subscript^ùõΩùëó^ùúésubscriptùëùùëóùëò1Œ¶subscript^ùõΩùëóùëò^ùúép_{j}=1-\Phi\left(\frac{\hat{\beta}_{j}}{\hat{\sigma}}\right),\quad p_{jk}=1-\Phi\left(\frac{\hat{\beta}_{jk}}{\hat{\sigma}}\right). Note that the constructed pùëùp-values may have some dependence due to sharing œÉ^^ùúé\hat{\sigma}. However as demonstrated experimentally in Section H, STAR¬†still seems to control the FDR¬†when correlations are not too large.

Finally, we apply STAR¬†on the pùëùp-values defined in (20) with Œ±=0.2ùõº0.2\alpha=0.2 using the accumulation function h‚Äã(p)=2‚ÄãI‚Äã(p‚â•0.5)‚Ñéùëù2ùêºùëù0.5h(p)=2I(p\geq 0.5) and the canonical scores. The selected variables include all main effects and three interaction effects: A√óB,A√óD,C√óDùê¥ùêµùê¥ùê∑ùê∂ùê∑A\times B,A\times D,C\times D. This model identifies more effects than those in Jaynes et¬†al. (2013). To illustrate the performance of the selection procedure, we refit a linear model using these variables and find that all selected variables are marginally significant except Cùê∂C. The estimate and the pùëùp-values for both full model and refitted model are reported in Table¬†2. This suggests that STAR¬†may have successfully identified the important effects with the guarantee that the FDR¬†is controlled at level 0.20.20.2.

Appendix H Sensitivity analysis

In this Section, we examine the performance of STAR¬†in the presense of correlated pùëùp-values in all three cases considered in Section 4, D and 5. We generate pùëùp-values from one-sided normal test with

pj=1‚àíŒ¶‚Äã(zi),where¬†‚Äãz=(z1,‚Ä¶,zn)‚àºN‚Äã(Œº,Œ£).formulae-sequencesubscriptùëùùëó1Œ¶subscriptùëßùëñwhere¬†ùëßsubscriptùëß1‚Ä¶subscriptùëßùëõsimilar-toùëÅùúáŒ£p_{j}=1-\Phi(z_{i}),\quad\mbox{where }z=(z_{1},\ldots,z_{n})\sim N(\mu,\Sigma).

Appendix I Benefit of Using Masking Functions

I.1 Asymptotic false discovery rate and power

In this section, we investigate the performance of our method under certain asymptotic regimes. The goal of this section is to characterize the benefit of using the masking function through the comparison between our method and the plain accumulation test. For illustration, we focus on the cases without structural constraints, namely ùí¶=2[n]ùí¶superscript2delimited-[]ùëõ\mathcal{K}=2^{[n]}. Additionally, we restrict the attention into the non-interactive version of our method that computes a score TisubscriptùëáùëñT_{i} for each p-value, described in Section 3, only in the initial stage using {xi,g‚Äã(pi)}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñùëîsubscriptùëùùëñùëñ1ùëõ\{x_{i},g(p_{i})\}_{i=1}^{n} and never updates it. This is equivalent to the accumulation test with p-values sorted by TisubscriptùëáùëñT_{i}. It is worth emphasizing that even in this basic setting where our method certainly loses many advantageous features, we can still observe the gain of using masking functions. The power analysis for interactive versions under general structural constraints is left to the future research.

The aforementioned non-interactive version can be equivalently formulated as rejecting all p-values less than or equal to t^nsubscript^ùë°ùëõ\hat{t}_{n}, where

t^n=sup{t:h‚Äã(1)+‚àëi=1nh‚Äã(pi)‚ÄãI‚Äã(Ti‚â§t)1+‚àëi=1nI‚Äã(Ti‚â§t)‚â§Œ±}.subscript^ùë°ùëõsupremumconditional-setùë°‚Ñé1superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõ‚Ñésubscriptùëùùëñùêºsubscriptùëáùëñùë°1superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõùêºsubscriptùëáùëñùë°ùõº\hat{t}_{n}=\sup\left\{t:\frac{h(1)+\sum_{i=1}^{n}h(p_{i})I(T_{i}\leq t)}{1+\sum_{i=1}^{n}I(T_{i}\leq t)}\leq\alpha\right\}. (21)

for some functions F‚Äã(t)ùêπùë°F(t) and H‚Äã(t)ùêªùë°H(t), which are not necessarily continuous. Note that both F‚Äã(t)ùêπùë°F(t) and H‚Äã(t)ùêªùë°H(t) are non-decreasing with F‚Äã(0)=H‚Äã(0)=0ùêπ0ùêª00F(0)=H(0)=0 and we can assume F‚Äã(t)>0ùêπùë°0F(t)>0 for all t‚àà(0,1]ùë°01t\in(0,1] without loss of generality; otherwise if t0=sup{t:F‚Äã(t)=0}subscriptùë°0supremumconditional-setùë°ùêπùë°0t_{0}=\sup\{t:F(t)=0\} we can tranform TisubscriptùëáùëñT_{i} to (Ti‚àít0)/(1‚àít0)subscriptùëáùëñsubscriptùë°01subscriptùë°0(T_{i}-t_{0})/(1-t_{0}). Remark I.2.

If HŒ±‚Äã(t)subscriptùêªùõºùë°H_{\alpha}(t) is continuous, then the condition (26) can be removed from part 1 and part 3. This is because if there exists t>t‚àóùë°superscriptùë°t>t^{*} such that

Lemma I.1 enables us to compute the asymptotic false discovery rate and power. To be precise, the false discovery proportion and the true positive rate are defined as

FDPn‚âú‚àëi=1nI‚Äã(hi=0,Ti‚â§t^n)‚àëi=1nI‚Äã(Ti‚â§t^n),TPRn=‚àëi=1nI‚Äã(hi=1,Ti‚â§t^n)‚àëi=1nI‚Äã(hi=1),formulae-sequence‚âúsubscriptFDPùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõùêºformulae-sequencesubscript‚Ñéùëñ0subscriptùëáùëñsubscript^ùë°ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõùêºsubscriptùëáùëñsubscript^ùë°ùëõsubscriptTPRùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõùêºformulae-sequencesubscript‚Ñéùëñ1subscriptùëáùëñsubscript^ùë°ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõùêºsubscript‚Ñéùëñ1\textnormal{FDP}_{n}\triangleq\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}I(h_{i}=0,T_{i}\leq\hat{t}_{n})}{\sum_{i=1}^{n}I(T_{i}\leq\hat{t}_{n})},\quad\textnormal{TPR}_{n}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}I(h_{i}=1,T_{i}\leq\hat{t}_{n})}{\sum_{i=1}^{n}I(h_{i}=1)},

where hi=1subscript‚Ñéùëñ1h_{i}=1 iff HisubscriptùêªùëñH_{i} is false. Then by definition the false discovery rate and the power can be written as

FDRn=ùîº‚Äã[FDPn],Pown=ùîº‚Äã[TPRn].formulae-sequencesubscriptFDRùëõùîºdelimited-[]subscriptFDPùëõsubscriptPowùëõùîºdelimited-[]subscriptTPRùëõ\textnormal{FDR}_{n}=\mathbb{E}[\textnormal{FDP}_{n}],\quad\textnormal{Pow}_{n}=\mathbb{E}[\textnormal{TPR}_{n}].

Assume that for all t‚àà[0,1]ùë°01t\in[0,1],

for some functions F0‚Äã(t)subscriptùêπ0ùë°F_{0}(t) and F1‚Äã(t)subscriptùêπ1ùë°F_{1}(t). Note that

Lemma I.4.

I.2 Re-analysis of accumulation tests

The accumulation test of Li & Barber (2016) corresponds to the choice Ti=i/nsubscriptùëáùëñùëñùëõT_{i}=i/n. In this case,

F1‚Äã(t)=limn‚Üí‚àû1n‚Äã‚àëi=1‚åän‚Äãt‚åãI‚Äã(hi=1)=limn‚Üí‚àû‚åän‚Äãt‚åãn‚Äã1‚åän‚Äãt‚åã‚Äã‚àëi=1‚åän‚Äãt‚åãI‚Äã(hi=1)=t‚Äãf‚Äã(t).subscriptùêπ1ùë°subscript‚Üíùëõ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõùë°ùêºsubscript‚Ñéùëñ1subscript‚Üíùëõùëõùë°ùëõ1ùëõùë°superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõùë°ùêºsubscript‚Ñéùëñ1ùë°ùëìùë°F_{1}(t)=\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{\lfloor nt\rfloor}I(h_{i}=1)=\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\frac{\lfloor nt\rfloor}{n}\frac{1}{\lfloor nt\rfloor}\sum_{i=1}^{\lfloor nt\rfloor}I(h_{i}=1)=tf(t).

Similarly,

F0‚Äã(t)=t‚Äã(1‚àíf‚Äã(t)),F‚Äã(t)=t.formulae-sequencesubscriptùêπ0ùë°ùë°1ùëìùë°ùêπùë°ùë°F_{0}(t)=t(1-f(t)),\quad F(t)=t.

Let Œº=ùîº1‚Äãh‚Äã(pi)ùúásubscriptùîº1‚Ñésubscriptùëùùëñ\mu=\mathbb{E}_{1}h(p_{i}),

H‚Äã(t)=F0‚Äã(t)+limn‚Üí‚àû1n‚Äã‚àëi=1‚åän‚Äãt‚åãI‚Äã(hi=1)‚ÄãŒº=t‚Äã(1‚àíf‚Äã(t))+Œº‚Äãt‚Äãf‚Äã(t)=t‚Äã(1‚àí(1‚àíŒº)‚Äãf‚Äã(t)).ùêªùë°subscriptùêπ0ùë°subscript‚Üíùëõ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõùë°ùêºsubscript‚Ñéùëñ1ùúáùë°1ùëìùë°ùúáùë°ùëìùë°ùë°11ùúáùëìùë°H(t)=F_{0}(t)+\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{\lfloor nt\rfloor}I(h_{i}=1)\mu=t(1-f(t))+\mu tf(t)=t(1-(1-\mu)f(t)).

By definition (24),

tAT‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùë°AT\displaystyle t_{\mathrm{AT}}^{*} =sup{t‚àà[0,1]:H‚Äã(t)‚â§Œ±‚ÄãF‚Äã(t)}=sup{t‚àà[0,1]:t‚Äã(1‚àí(1‚àíŒº)‚Äãf‚Äã(t))‚â§Œ±‚Äãt}absentsupremumconditional-setùë°01ùêªùë°ùõºùêπùë°supremumconditional-setùë°01ùë°11ùúáùëìùë°ùõºùë°\displaystyle=\sup\{t\in[0,1]:H(t)\leq\alpha F(t)\}=\sup\{t\in[0,1]:t(1-(1-\mu)f(t))\leq\alpha t\}
=sup{t‚àà[0,1]:f‚Äã(t)‚â•1‚àíŒ±1‚àíŒº}.absentsupremumconditional-setùë°01ùëìùë°1ùõº1ùúá\displaystyle=\sup\left\{t\in[0,1]:f(t)\geq\frac{1-\alpha}{1-\mu}\right\}. (30)

Note that tAT‚àó>0superscriptsubscriptùë°AT0t_{\mathrm{AT}}^{*}>0 only if Œº‚â•Œ±ùúáùõº\mu\geq\alpha since f‚Äã(t)‚â§1ùëìùë°1f(t)\leq 1 for any t‚àà[0,1]ùë°01t\in[0,1]. If f‚Äã(t)ùëìùë°f(t) is non-increasing and t‚Äãf‚Äã(t)ùë°ùëìùë°tf(t) is non-decreasing, as considered in Li & Barber (2016), it is easy to verify the conditions (26) and (27) in Lemma I.1. Thus, by Theorem I.3, if tAT‚àó>0superscriptsubscriptùë°AT0t_{\mathrm{AT}}^{*}>0,

I.4 Analysis of our method with informative pre-ordering

When the pre-ordering is indeed informative in the sense that f‚Äã(t)ùëìùë°f(t) is decreasing with f‚Äã(1)<(1‚àíŒ±)/(1‚àíŒº)ùëì11ùõº1ùúáf(1)<(1-\alpha)/(1-\mu) so that tAT‚àó>0superscriptsubscriptùë°AT0t_{\mathrm{AT}}^{*}>0. Ti=min‚Å°{in,g‚Äã(pi)b}subscriptùëáùëñùëñùëõùëîsubscriptùëùùëñùëèT_{i}=\min\left\{\frac{i}{n},\frac{g(p_{i})}{b}\right\} (34)

Before analyzing this procedure rigorously in theory, we illustrate it using a simple simulation. Suppose the p-values are computed from one-sided z-tests, i.e.

For each setting the FDP¬†and the power are recorded for 100001000010000 independent replicates. The box-plots are displayed in Figure 31. The advantage of using masking functions is clear: it reduces the variability of FDP¬†while enhances the power significantly.

Therefore, even with an informative pre-ordering, using the masking function may further improve the power. This inspires an interesting question on how to combine the pre-ordering and the masked p-values in an optimal way to enhance power. However, this is beyond the main focus of this paper and we leave it to future research.
